results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film shows scenes of travelling around the Victorian countryside on motorcycles (motorbikes).

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 motorcycles being filmed from a vehicle travelling alongside
00:00:20:00 motorcycle rider with passenger wearing a beret
00:00:40:00 motorcycle riders gather for the camera at the Atlantic Garage in Ballarat
00:01:17:00 riding the motorcycles down a dusty road

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film captures Jack’s family and friends enjoying their scrambler motor bikes in muddy conditions at Korweinguboora, near Ballarat, Victoria. There are also visits to Geelong Racecourse and to Melbourne for some rowing races.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 a member of Jack’s circle on a motorbike
00:00:25:00 a group likely to be members of the Radio Cabs cooperative that Jack and Marie established in Ballarat
00:00:28:00 translucent title across the screen, ‘Ballarat Harley Club Mud Scrambles at Korweinguboora…’
00:00:39:00 riding the muddy track with sidecars
00:01:00:00 scrambling motorcycle riders
00:01:17:00 a fall in the mud for a motorcyclist
00:01:25:00 two stylishly dressed women pose for the camera
00:01:48:00 horses racing at Geelong Racecourse followed by the camera panning out over the Racecourse attendees from a higher vantage point
00:02:31:00 two men cycling through a quiet town street
00:03:01:00 two women and a man posing for the camera in front of the Eureka Stockade Memorial in what appears to be a cold wind
00:03:14:00 rowing races on a river
00:03:30:00 strolling through public gardens

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film contains street scenes in Bendigo, a drive to the Tambo River in Gippsland Victoria, looking for mushrooms in a farm paddock, some spectacular hairstyles and wonderful 1940s clothes.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:23:00 a tram moves along a street with shops in the background in Bendigo
00:00:34:00 glimpse of a ‘Bendigo’ advertising sign on a building
00:00:40:00 palm trees and a lake in the Bendigo Botanic Gardens
00:00:57:00 sign for ‘Bendigo Bitter Beer’ on a building
00:01:07:00 cows in a slightly hilly paddock and then a house on the hill
00:01:45:00 a car parked on a bridge and a river before the sign ‘Tambo River’
00:01:47:00 a small group of a child, two women and an older man who appears to be a farmer climbing through a wire fence into a paddock. The farmer uses the old method of a foot holding down the lower fence wire and a hand holding up the top wire for his companions to get through the gap comfortably
00:02:14:00 as the women are holding baskets we can presume the group are in the paddock to collect mushrooms; the women both have wonderful, thick curly hairstyles
00:02:30:00 the camera is filming from inside a car travelling down a country road
00:02:47:00 a scene at the races where two women are surprised by and smiling at the camera

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film features a parade of cars, trucks and buses in Ballarat and a visit to a swimming pool where Jack includes some special effects of diving into the pool. There is also a scene where two women are posing for the camera next to a car. It becomes evident that the older stately woman is shy of the camera but the endearing younger woman is very confident as she clowns around in her very 1940s trousers and beret outfit.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a parade of vehicles in Ballarat
00:00:50:00 two women stand in front of a car; one is joking around for the camera
00:01:05:00 at a swimming pool, a group of women onlookers watch a men diving into the water; the motion is reversed in a special effect so that we watch the diving in and back out of the pool
00:02:25:00 swimmers give an exhibition of the Australian Crawl (freestyle)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film shows an outing to the local horse races, a visit to a fast flowing river and some street scenes in Ballarat in the 1940s.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 horses racing on a country race track
00:00:35:00 racing official on horseback
00:00:51:00 ‘S E Chamberlain’ bookmaker bag is sighted in the background while an older gentleman in a three piece suit and hat ambles past the camera
00:01:10:00 a group of women at the races wearing hats including a scarf knotted at the front in a 1940s style
00:01:22:00 a man gestures to the camera that he has lost his bet
00:02:01:00 advertising sign for ‘Longhurst Quality Bread’
00:02:15:00 a travelling tram, tram tracks, cars and trucks on Ballarat streets, including Sturt Street
00:02:25:00 a service station called Atlantic Garage
00:02:30:00 two men walking around a turbulent waterway
00:03:03:00 Ballarat rooftops from a high vantage point
00:03:50:00 Ballarat street scene focussing on some people walking toward the camera wearing good examples of fashionable 1940s style clothes
00:04:08:00 Ballarat Town Hall
00:04:10:00 a main shopping street in Ballarat showing a ‘Myer Store’ verandah
results.description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film shows an outing to the local horse races, a visit to a fast flowing river and some street scenes in Ballarat in the 1940s.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 horses racing on a country race track
00:00:35:00 racing official on horseback
00:00:51:00 ‘S E Chamberlain’ bookmaker bag is sighted in the background while an older gentleman in a three piece suit and hat ambles past the camera
00:01:10:00 a group of women at the races wearing hats including a scarf knotted at the front in a 1940s style
00:01:22:00 a man gestures to the camera that he has lost his bet
00:02:01:00 advertising sign for ‘Longhurst Quality Bread’
00:02:15:00 a travelling tram, tram tracks, cars and trucks on Ballarat streets, including Sturt Street
00:02:25:00 a service station called Atlantic Garage
00:02:30:00 two men walking around a turbulent waterway
00:03:03:00 Ballarat rooftops from a high vantage point
00:03:50:00 Ballarat street scene focussing on some people walking toward the camera wearing good examples of fashionable 1940s style clothes
00:04:08:00 Ballarat Town Hall
00:04:10:00 a main shopping street in Ballarat showing a ‘Myer Store’ verandah

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows the Hayes family on a holiday when they are young parents with their young daughters. The family travels to The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd), the coastal town of Warrnambool, and the Eildon Weir and Eildon Lake, all in Victoria, before heading to Sydney in New South Wales.

Scenes from a zoo at the time could be distressing to some viewers as contemporary zoological standards are very different to those of the early 1950s.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 children and their parents on board a carnival train ride and the young Hayes girls with enormous bows in their hair stand for the camera, one very unsure and one laughing
00:00:22:00 riding on top of an elephant and monkeys swinging in their cage, followed by goats, a glimpse of a hippopotamus, bears, swimming penguins and a pacing tiger
00:02:26:00 the young Hayes girls sit with their father on a bench
00:02:30:00 Mr and Mrs Hayes and one of the girls at a lookout over a mountain range, likely to be The Grampians (Gariwerd/Geriwerd) in Victoria
00:02:55:00 wandering along creeks and bush and near dramatic waterfalls
00:03:41:00 family members smile at the camera, some lovely sunglasses and one of the Hayes girls shows her tiny handbag to the camera
00:04:00:00 one of the children hand feeds a bottle of milk to a lamb before taking it for a walk on a lead followed by some horse riding lessons
00:04:52:00 a lovely country house set against the mountains in the immediate background and an array of 1940s to 1950s cars parked alongside
00:05:42:00 a sign ‘Silverband Falls’
00:06:07:00 hand feeding cows with food scraps
00:06:30:00 community races for children and adults
00:07:23:00 views of the Eildon Weir and boats on Lake Eildon
00:08:00:00 the girls sit on some used cable spools
00:08:23:00 a small candlelit memorial to King George VI
00:08:30:00 swimming in a pool while an airplane flies overhead
00:09:20:00 a large ferry and the Sydney Harbour Bridge from a distance and up-close followed by street scenes in Sydney
00:10:26:00 beachgoers on the sand, possibly at Manly in Sydney and a family and or friends gathering for the camera
00:11:10:00 views of Sydney’s older city buildings including the AWA building and tower (Amalgamated Wireless Australasia)
00:11:15:00 the koala enclosure at the zoo followed by more elephant rides

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexander’s son Mac.

This reel captures the excitement of the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne with footage of the decorated buildings in the city featuring the department stores of the era – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store and Woolworths. Also included is a family wedding and scenes from the beach.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of Melbourne’s decorated department stores – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store (as it was named then) and Woolworths
00:01:42:00 family wedding scenes
00:02:54:00 wedding shots at the church including 1950s fashion style
00:03:24:00 family members at the beach show off the style of the day – striped towels, and a range of clothes from trousers to bathers with ‘shirring’ and sundresses

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexandar’s son Mac.

This reel features scenes of the family in the countryside, walking, driving and a visit to the ‘Sea Winds Cafe’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:45:00 after views of a large waterway and the countryside, people standing by a 1940s car and a ‘Bonds Greyhound Line’ bus
00:01:33:00 road footage taken from inside the car
00:02:00:00 women and dog wandering along through grassland
00:02:30:00 woman knitting in a deckchair
00:03:05:00 a cafe for which we see a glimpse of the sign before the footage ends, ‘Sea Winds Cafe’

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel is of the filmmaker’s daughter Jean and her visitor, Toddy. Toddy is in military uniform when he rounds a corner of a house to chat happily to Jean, with their dog and pet birds. While on leave from the RAF, Toddy was billeted to the family home in Essendon during his time in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:01:00 Toddy enters the frame from a side path of to visit Jean at her home
00:00:12:00 Jean leans out the window to chat to Toddy
00:00:16:00 Toddy enthusiastically welcomes a dog into the scene
00:00:20:00 Jean presents two pet birds on her arm for the camera

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander (Alex) Nicoll (1898–1968) grew up in Princes Hill in Melbourne.

As a young man, and after working in various capacities, Alex met wealthy business owner Arthur Thomas who assisted him into business running an import agency at Tasmania House in Flinders Lane. Alex would enjoy a lifelong involvement with Melbourne’s ‘rag trade’ (clothing business) in Flinders Lane, including serving for some years as the President of the Victorian Softgoods Association.

In the 1930s Alex inherited an Agfa 16mm camera, projector and collapsible screen from Arthur Thomas who had been a keen photographer, and over the 1940s and 1950s would capture wonderful moments around Melbourne such as the celebrations for the 1956 Olympics and visits to the beaches of Port Phillip Bay.

After Alexander died, his son Mac continued the family filming enthusiasm in the 1960s and 1970s. Around 2005, the Nicoll family decided to donate most of their collection of films to ACMI.

This reel captures a military parade likely to be sometime in the 1940s down Alexandra Parade, Moonee Ponds and some garden views.

Selected highlight list:

00:00:00:05 a crowd lines the street (most likely Mt Alexander Road near Moonee Ponds Town Hall, the family lived in Essendon)
00:00:00:28 soldiers parade down the street before a crowd of onlookers
00:00:00:51 parade passes a dais on which people stand, one in a mayoral robe and chain of office
00:01:12:00 military trucks and equipment can be seen in the parade
00:01:38:00 soldiers relaxing on the lawn with members of the crowd after the parade
